content: The "Tech Bond Initiative of 2001" aims to expand broadband access through tech bonds, providing incentives for State and local governments. This Act recognizes the importance of high-speed Internet for businesses and addresses the lack of access in certain areas. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 would offer credits to holders of qualified technology bonds. The "Tech Bond Initiative of 2001" aims to expand broadband access through tech bonds, providing incentives for State and local governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 would offer credits to holders of qualified technology bonds. The "Tech Bond Initiative of 2001" offers tax credits to holders of qualified technology bonds based on the credit rate determined by the Secretary each month. The Secretary determines a credit rate for bonds issued each month to allow issuance without discount or interest cost. The credit allowed for a taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and other credits. A qualified technology bond is defined as a bond where 95% or more of the proceeds are used for technology purposes. The qualified project bond must meet specific criteria, including using 95% of proceeds for the project, being issued by a local government where the project is located, designated for this purpose, approved by the Secretary of Commerce, and having a maximum term of 15 years. A qualified project refers to expanding broadband telecommunications services in a designated area. The Secretary of Commerce designates qualified projects for expanding telecommunications services in underserved or rural areas lacking high-speed Internet connections. The Secretary of Commerce designates qualified projects for expanding telecommunications services in underserved or rural areas lacking high-speed Internet connections. There is a national technology bond limitation of $100,000,000 for certain years, with allocations made by the Secretary among designated projects. The maximum aggregate face amount of bonds issued for qualified projects in a calendar year cannot exceed the limitation amount allocated to each project. Any excess national technology limitation amount from the previous year can be carried over to the following year. The term "bond" includes any obligation for this purpose. The term 'bond' includes any obligation, the 'credit allowance date' refers to the last day of the 1-year period after issuance, and 'State' means the States and the District of Columbia. Gross income includes the credit allowed to the taxpayer under this section, treated as interest income. Special rules apply to partnerships, S corporations, and other pass-thru entities. Rules similar to section 41(g) apply to the credit for partnerships, trusts, S corporations, or other pass-thru entities. Qualified technology bond holders in regulated investment companies receive the credit through procedures set by the Secretary. The credit for holding a qualified technology bond is treated as estimated tax payment for sections 6654 and 6655. Issuers of qualified technology bonds must report accordingly. Issuers of qualified technology bonds must submit reports similar to those required under section 149(e). Reporting of credit on qualified technology bonds for interest payments is defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows the Secretary to prescribe regulations for reporting requirements related to qualified technology bonds. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of subparts for part IV of subchapter A. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows regulations for reporting requirements on qualified technology bonds. Section 6401(b)(1) is amended to include a new nonrefundable credit for holders of such bonds. Effective December 31, 2001, the amendments apply to obligations issued after that date.
